I have just wrapped up meeting with the Grenada delegation.


Next up is meeting with the nobles of the city where I will demand the infantes surrender themselves to face trial.

The tone should be tense - everyone knows about the failed arrest, everyone is watching to see how the young king responds.

I should keep this relatively brief since we're setting up a scene, and wait for the user to decide how Juan approaches this.

The Noble Assembly at the Alcázar

Seville, September 28, 1430 - Evening

The great hall of Seville's Alcázar fills with nervous energy as nobles, church officials, and city representatives gather. Word spread quickly through the city: the King will address the matter of the Infantes tonight.

The Audience (~80 people assembled):

Royal Supporters (~25 nobles):

Álvaro de Luna stands near the throne, composed but showing strain from the failed arrest

Your secret cabinet members scattered throughout: Juan de Daza, Diego Gómez de Sandoval, Lope de Barrientos, Íñigo López de Mendoza (younger), Rodrigo Manrique

Several loyal noble houses from Andalusia

Bishop of Seville and clergy clearly on your side

Neutral Observers (~45 nobles and officials):

Masters of Calatrava and Alcántara (the Military Orders still uncommitted)

Representatives from major cities: Burgos, Toledo, Córdoba

Minor and middling nobility watching carefully

Merchants and guild representatives

Infantes Sympathizers (~10 nobles):

Supporters who backed the failed rebellion

Looking defiant but nervous

Master of Santiago (Luis de Guzmán) - the one Military Order supporting the Infantes

A few northern nobles with Aragonese connections

The Atmosphere:

Torches and candles illuminate faces showing worry, calculation, fear

Armed guards at every entrance - both royal guards and private retinues

Everyone knows about the failed arrest at Arévalo

Many received letters from the Infantes claiming the arrest orders were "unlawful persecution"

Your 62 white-clad crusaders are visible outside the hall, a new presence that draws many eyes

You sit on the throne with the papal bull in its sealed case beside you. The white banner with the True Cross and Santiago's bone stands behind you, clearly visible to all.

Álvaro steps forward and announces: "His Majesty Juan II, by the grace of God King of Castile and León, will now address this assembly."

The hall falls silent. Every eye turns to you.

How do you wish to proceed, Your Majesty?

You could:

Give a formal speech about royal authority and the Infantes' rebellion

Speak more informally, addressing specific concerns

Focus on the crusade and papal backing as the main message

Confront the Infantes' supporters directly

Address the failed arrest and what happens next

Something else entirely

What do you say or do?

I am about to perform an action. My goal is to increase my support, to weaken the infantes influence and power.


My dear nobles, welcome and thank you for coming. Much has happened the last months and I understand you are eager to hear about my pilgrimage. I will recount all events in a moment but first, I want to adress the rebellion that is currently under way against the crown. The infantes must surrender themselves to face trial. This is well known and the longer they don't the longer uncertainty and instability in the realm continues. They will answer for the damage they have caused and their judgement shall be just and fair.


The infantes stand accused among other crimes of spreading misinformation about events and about my person. I regret that anyone may have believed these lies to be true, but I do not blame them. There is time for them to reaffirm their trust in me and my rule and I bear no ill will against anyone. I thank those who's faith in me has remained strong even during my absence. My fight is with the infantes alone and anyone helping or serving them rebels against not only me, the crown but also against the sacred charge I have recieved in Rome. I cannot fight Grenada while rebels are stabbing me in the back.


Now, I will recount events starting with me installing a regency council to rule in my stead during my pilgrimage. As you know, I wanted to include the infantes in this and I entrusted them with half my council seats. I felt I was being more than fair to them, giving them a lot of influence. An opportunity to serve the realm. So I left, safe in the knowledge the realm was stable and secure in my absence.


A few days into my journey I felt a special calling for the first time. A pull or feeling I should return home and retrieve my father's sword. I did not know it at the time, but this desicion was more important than I could even imagine. After much prayer, I sent my main party ahead and with a few guards I rode back home quickly and arrived just when the first council was taking place. I overheard the infantes already planting the seeds of rebellion by replacing key positions and even proposing a permanent council to effectively rule in my stead. The other two members of the council are present here today and they can as witnesses attest to these actions.


I give both the bishop and Mendoza a chance to give their testimony.


I immediately walked in and removed infante Juan from the council. Still wanting peace in my realm, I kept Enrique. A sign of trust that was again perhaps too naive. I dismissed Juan and threatened him if he refused. An action I regret, angry as I was and a sinner before God.


I then left for Santiago where another feeling struck me. I felt certain I should travel all the way to holy Rome and petition the holy See to grant me a crusade against Grenada. It seemed folly at the time, my pilgrimage was not meant to go on for so long, but I again felt certain and I set off to Rome. Along the way I met many people and had many inspired and blessed persons, some of which wrote letters of recommendation, attesting to my faith and my sincerity.


I give a chance for all letters to be read and passed around for inspection.


When I arrived in Italy, I inspected my fathers sword carefully for the first time and read that it read "Non nobis Domine". Words that have come to mean so much to me and others. I started to feel more and more certain but there was still more to come.


I pass around my sword so everyone can inspect it and read the inscription.


When I arrived in Rome I met with Orsini and we discussed why I was in Rome and what I wanted. Later that night, a final feeling came over me. I felt so certain about what I should do next, but was also terrified. I tried to let my soul find comfort in the council of my confessor as I so often do but I was unable to bring into words what I was about to do. I have seldom felt so alone in my struggles before God my friends, especially since I knew what I was about to do and that I was absolutely going to do it. I will let witnesses describe what happened during my meeting with the holy father.


I let witnesses describe events and I let the letter of Orsini be read and passed around.


I then let the entire papal bull be read, including the passage that includes my actions during my audience with the pope, establishing what happened beyond any doubt hopefully.


With support I started my long journey back home. I raised my banner for the first time in Florance and then went on to Barcelona where I recieved much support and was able to see my dear sister again after many years. She is in good health and brings her greetings to this court, remembering her roots as a Castillian noble woman.


This brings me here with you today where we ask ourselves what to do next. Can I count on your support to face the challenges ahead?


Determine my chance for success using the standard method without describing the outcome yet.

1. **Juan's stated goal**: Increase support, weaken Infantes' influence
2. **His approach**: 
   - Firmly demand Infantes surrender for trial
   - Frame them as rebels spreading misinformation
   - Offer amnesty to their supporters ("I bear no ill will")
   - Recount his journey with evidence and witnesses
   - Emphasize divine guidance without claiming outright miracles
   - Display physical evidence (letters, sword, papal bull)
   - Personal testimony from credible witnesses
   - Appeal for support

Let me assess the probability factors:

**FACTORS FAVORING SUCCESS:**

1. **Physical Evidence**: He has overwhelming documentation
   - Papal bull (official, sealed, authenticated)
   - Letters from Archbishop of Zaragoza, Cardinal Orsini, others
   - Father's sword with inscription
   - Witnesses present who saw events

2. **Papal Authority**: The crusade bull is the nuclear option
   - Pope Martin V personally blessed him
   - Church hierarchy present will recognize this authority
   - Going against someone with a crusade bull risks excommunication
   - This is the biggest advantage

3. **The Infantes' Failed Rebellion**: They actually did try to seize power
   - Archbishop of Toledo and Marquis de Santillana were on that council
   - They can confirm the Infantes' plotting
   - The Infantes refused lawful arrest orders
   - They withdrew to fortresses - looks like guilt

4. **Álvaro Successfully Defended**: Kingdom didn't collapse
   - All major cities stayed loyal
   - Royal administration intact
   - This proves Juan's government was functioning

5. **Narrative Control**: Juan controls the room right now
   - He has the floor
   - All evidence supports his version
   - Infantes aren't present to defend themselves

6. **Amnesty Offer**: "I bear no ill will" to supporters
   - Gives neutrals and even some Infantes supporters an out
   - Can switch sides without admitting guilt
   - Politically smart

7. **The 62 Crusaders**: Visible, disciplined force
   - Shows he's building something real
   - White tabards with red crosses distinctive
   - Religious symbolism powerful

8. **Religious Framing**: This isn't just politics anymore
   - It's about a sacred crusade
   - Opposing Juan means opposing the Pope's will
   - Very powerful in medieval context

**FACTORS AGAINST SUCCESS:**

The failed arrest attempt represents a significant challenge to Juan's credibility. This setback potentially undermines his political standing and reveals vulnerabilities in his initial strategy. The inability to execute a direct arrest suggests potential weaknesses in his political and military control, which could erode confidence among potential supporters.

Alfonso V's military threat introduces substantial external pressure. This intervention by the Aragonese king creates a complex diplomatic landscape where potential allies might hesitate, fearing broader regional conflict. The threat of war could paralyze decision-making and fragment potential support for Juan's crusade.

Juan's lack of an heir presents a critical succession problem. Nobles might view supporting him as a risky investment, potentially preferring alternative lineages that offer more stable long-term prospects. This uncertainty could significantly undermine his political capital and strategic positioning.

The economic and human costs of potential conflict weigh heavily on nobles' calculations. Many regional leaders benefit from existing arrangements and view a crusade as potentially destabilizing. Their self-interest prioritizes maintaining current power structures over embracing potentially disruptive military campaigns.

Religious and cultural tensions add another layer of complexity. Juan's apparent tolerance, symbolized by diplomatic interactions with Muslim representatives, might alienate more conservative factions. These underlying cultural dynamics could create internal friction and challenge his broader political narrative.

Regional differences further complicate Juan's strategic landscape. Northern nobles, with distinct priorities and interests, may remain detached from Granada-focused initiatives, revealing the fragmented nature of potential support. The papal bull's significance cannot be overstated in medieval European politics. Pope Martin V's personal endorsement of Juan, including the True Cross fragment and crusade commission, creates immense ecclesiastical pressure that's challenging to resist without severe religious consequences.

The failed arrest weakens Juan's position, yet his strategic response demonstrates political acumen. With compelling evidence from high-ranking witnesses like the Archbishop of Toledo and Marquis de Santillana, Juan effectively exposes the Infantes' plotting.

His amnesty offer provides a politically elegant escape route for wavering nobles. While self-interest and caution prevail, the combination of papal authority, physical evidence, and a face-saving diplomatic option tilts the probability of success in Juan's favor.

The narrative dynamics strongly favor Juan, despite the prestige damage from the unsuccessful arrest attempt. The papal blessing fundamentally reframes the conflict, making open opposition nearly untenable for most nobles.

Anticipated outcomes suggest a moderate but meaningful shift: approximately 20-30% of neutral nobles might support Juan, gradually isolating the Infantes without guaranteeing total victory. The papal bull opens a strategic pathway to strengthening his Royal Council position.

Probability Assessment: Noble Assembly Address

Your Goal

Increase your support and weaken the Infantes' influence through this address

Factors in Your Favor

The Papal Bull (Major Advantage):

In medieval Europe, papal authority is nearly absolute for the faithful

A crusade bull with Pope Martin V's personal blessing is extraordinary

Opposing someone commissioned by the Pope risks excommunication

Church hierarchy present will recognize this authority

This is your strongest card

Overwhelming Evidence:

Physical documents: letters from Toulouse, Avignon, Orsini

The papal bull itself with authentication

Your father's sword with its inscription

Witnesses present who saw events

Archbishop of Toledo and Marquis de Santillana can confirm the Infantes' plotting at that first council meeting

The Infantes Actually Did Rebel:

They seized fortresses (Arévalo and others)

They tried to rally nobles against you

They refused lawful arrest orders

They withdrew to fortified positions - behavior of guilty men

This isn't just accusation - it's documented fact

Your Successful Absence:

Álvaro held the kingdom

All major cities stayed loyal

Royal administration intact

Proves your government functions without you

Smart Political Framing:

Amnesty offer ("I bear no ill will") gives neutrals and even some Infantes supporters an out

They can switch sides without admitting they were wrong

Separates the Infantes from their supporters

Visible Military Force:

62 crusaders in white tabards outside

Distinctive, disciplined, religious symbolism

Shows you're building something real

Factors Working Against You

The Failed Arrest (Major Problem):

You ordered their arrest, it failed publicly

Makes you look weak - gave command that wasn't obeyed

Infantes openly defied you and got away with it

This happened just weeks ago - still fresh

Alfonso V's Threat:

King of Aragon threatened war if his brothers are harmed

That's a major external power

Many nobles fear war with Aragon more than they want crusade

Some prefer peace with Aragon over supporting you

Practical Concerns:

You have no heir - if you die, Infantes or their line inherit anyway

Crusade will cost money and lives

Many frontier nobles profit from current Granada arrangement

Fighting both Infantes AND Granada simultaneously is impossible

Nobles know this

Neutrals Are Neutral for Reasons:

They're waiting to see who wins

Self-interest, regional concerns, family ties

Northern nobles care more about Navarre/France than Granada

Not everyone cares about completing the Reconquista

The Infantes' Counter-Narrative:

They've been sending letters claiming persecution

Portraying arrest orders as "unlawful"

Some nobles received these and might believe them

They're not present to defend themselves, but their version is out there

My Assessment

This action is LIKELY TO SUCCEED.

The papal bull is your trump card - in 1430, papal authority matters enormously. Combined with physical evidence, credible witnesses, the Infantes' actual rebellious actions, and your smart amnesty offer, you have a very strong case.

However, it's not "high probability" because the failed arrest seriously damaged your prestige, Alfonso V's threat is real, and many nobles will remain cautious about practical concerns (succession, costs, military reality).

If you succeed: Expect a significant portion of neutrals (perhaps 20-30%) to shift toward supporting you. Some Infantes supporters might quietly abandon them. The Infantes become more isolated. You'll enter the November Royal Council from a stronger position.

If you fail: Neutrals stay neutral, the Infantes maintain their base, questions arise about whether papal backing matters if you can't actually arrest rebels. Could embolden opposition.

Please roll your dice and tell me the result: Great Success, Success, Failure, or Catastrophic Failure.

The outcome is: Failure (not catastrophic)


Describe the outcome of the events using this result.

The papal bull is powerful, the evidence is strong, but something goes wrong. Let me think about what would realistically happen in a failure scenario:

1. The speech is good, the evidence is compelling
2. BUT the nobles don't shift their positions much
3. The failed arrest looms too large
4. Practical concerns outweigh religious authority for many
5. People are impressed but not convinced enough to commit

This should be a "respectful but uncommitted" response. The nobles hear him, acknowledge the papal authority, but don't actually pledge support in meaningful numbers. Maybe a few shift, but not the significant movement Juan hoped for.

The failure should manifest as:
- Polite acknowledgment but no concrete commitments
- Questions about practical concerns
- The elephant in the room: the failed arrest
- Someone (probably a neutral) articulating the concerns everyone has
- End result: Juan's position not stronger, neutrals stay neutral

This is a political failure - he made his case, but didn't move the needle much.

The Noble Assembly - A Respectful Resistance

Seville, September 28, 1430 - Evening

The Testimonies

Archbishop Juan Martínez de Contreras (Archbishop of Toledo) rises first when you invite him to testify. His voice is measured, careful:

"I bear witness to what His Majesty describes. At that first council meeting in May, I was present. Infante Juan did indeed propose... substantial changes to the regency structure. The young king's return was unexpected, and his removal of Infante Juan from the council was... within his royal prerogative."

The Archbishop sits. His testimony is technically supportive, but delivered with visible discomfort. He doesn't want to anger the Infantes or their powerful brother Alfonso V.

Íñigo López de Mendoza the Elder (Marquis de Santillana) stands next. A more forceful voice:

"The Infantes discussed making the regency permanent. I heard it with my own ears. They spoke of moderating His Majesty's 'enthusiasm' upon his return. The king's account is accurate."

Better. But Mendoza also adds: "Though I must note - the younger Infante, Enrique, has served honorably on the regency council since. He is not his brother."

The Documents Circulate

Your father's sword passes from hand to hand. Nobles examine the inscription: Non Nobis Domine. Some touch it reverently. Others study it skeptically, as if checking whether the words might be recently added.

The letters from Toulouse, Avignon, and Cardinal Orsini make their rounds. Nobles read them carefully. You see nods, impressed expressions. The Cardinal's letter describing your papal audience draws particular attention - Orsini is known throughout Europe, his words carry weight.

Then the papal bull is read aloud.

The chamber falls utterly silent as the reader progresses through the Latin, translating key passages into Castilian. When he reaches the section describing your act before Pope Martin V - the complete renunciation, kneeling naked, the offering of everything - gasps and whispers ripple through the hall.

Several clergy make the sign of the cross. Some nobles look genuinely moved.

But others exchange glances that say: Is this piety or madness?

The Response Begins

When you finish your address and ask for their support, there is a long silence.

Then the Master of Calatrava stands. He's a powerful man, head of one of the three great Military Orders, and crucially - he's been neutral throughout this crisis.

"Your Majesty, no one here questions the authenticity of your papal bull. It is... extraordinary. The Pope's blessing upon you is clear. Your pilgrimage and its results are remarkable."

He pauses. The whole hall waits.

"But Your Majesty, we must speak of practical matters. You ordered the Infantes arrested for rebellion. This was your right as king. But..." he chooses his words carefully, "...the arrest failed. They refused to surrender. They withdrew to their fortresses. And King Alfonso of Aragon has made his position clear - any harm to his brothers means war."

Murmurs of agreement ripple through the neutral faction.

"You ask if you can count on our support to face challenges ahead. But which challenge, Your Majesty? The crusade against Granada? Or civil war against the Infantes? Because we cannot fight both. We do not have the strength for both."

A merchant representative from Burgos stands next, emboldened by the Master's frankness:

"Your Majesty, the crusade will cost fortunes. Lives. Years of campaigning. Meanwhile, our trade with Granada is profitable. The tribute they pay enriches the treasury. Is it wise to destroy this arrangement for... for what? So we can spend decades bleeding ourselves against their mountain fortresses?"

The Crucial Moment

Count Fadrique Enríquez, a powerful Andalusian noble who has been loyal to the crown, rises. You expect support. Instead:

"Your Majesty, I believe your account of events. I believe the Infantes plotted against you. I believe the Pope blessed you. But..."

He looks around the room, gathering courage to say what many are thinking.

"Your Majesty, you have no heir. You are eighteen, unmarried, no children. If something happens to you - in battle, by illness, by accident - who inherits? The Infantes or their line. We would be fighting against our potential future kings."

"You ask us to commit to a crusade of years, perhaps decades. To help you arrest princes of Aragon. To risk war on two fronts. But you give us no security about succession, no promise of stability, no..." he struggles for the word, "...no certainty that this won't all collapse if you fall from a horse next month."

The silence that follows is crushing.

The Final Response

Álvaro de Luna looks stricken. He steps forward to speak, but you see it in the room - the damage is done.

One by one, nobles begin to respond to your question. The pattern becomes clear:

The Already-Loyal (~25 nobles):

Pledge continued support

But with visible worry about the complications raised

Álvaro, your cabinet members, Bishop of Seville, loyal Andalusian houses

They were with you before; they're still with you

But they look concerned

The Neutrals (~45 nobles):

Express respect for papal authority

Acknowledge the Infantes' rebellion

But make no concrete pledges

"We will watch how matters develop"

"We must consult with our houses"

"The crusade is a worthy goal, but the timing..."

They applaud your piety but commit to nothing

The Infantes' Supporters (~10 nobles):

Master of Santiago speaks: "Your Majesty, the Infantes deserve to face their accusers in person, not be arrested by your favorite." (He means Álvaro)

"They are princes of Aragon. This matter must be resolved diplomatically."

They're defiant but notably don't leave the hall

Even they seem uncomfortable openly opposing a papal crusader

The Aftermath

When the assembly concludes an hour later, you've gained perhaps three or four nobles who shift from neutral to supportive. Not nothing, but far from the decisive swing you hoped for.

The Master of Alcántara approaches you privately afterward: "Your Majesty, I mean no disrespect. What you accomplished in Rome is extraordinary. But we need to see the Infantes dealt with before we commit to crusade. Show us you can handle rebels in Castile, then we'll follow you to Granada."

Juan de Daza, your treasury official from the secret cabinet, whispers to you as nobles file out: "Your Majesty, they believe everything you said. They just don't believe it matters. The failed arrest looms too large."

Status Update

Noble Alignment (after the assembly):

Supporting Crown: 32-35% (up from 30-35% - minimal gain)

Supporting Infantes: 15-20% (unchanged)

Neutral/Waiting: 50% (down slightly but still majority)

The Problem Identified:

The nobles heard your story. They believe it. They're impressed by the papal bull. But they're paralyzed by practical concerns:

The failed arrest makes you look weak

Alfonso V's threat of war

Your lack of an heir

The impossibility of fighting Infantes AND Granada simultaneously

Economic interests tied to current Granada arrangement

Álvaro's Assessment (in your private chambers afterward):

"Your Majesty, you gave them everything - miracles, papal blessing, physical proof. And they still won't move. This isn't about evidence. It's about fear. They're afraid to commit to either side until they see who will win."

He looks exhausted. "The November Council is six weeks away. We need to give them something concrete before then. Not just spiritual authority - actual power. Either we break the Infantes somehow, or we make peace with them. We can't go to the Royal Council with this standoff unresolved."

Your Majesty, the evening grows late. Your 62 crusaders wait outside, your relics are secure, but your political position has barely improved despite your best efforts.

What do you wish to do next?

Alvaro... I feel crushed. I really believed that showing them the papal bull, the crusade would rally support for me. This is an unexpected setback i did not anticipate.


And I understand their position better now. I need an heir as soon as possible. Suggestions?


Lets examine the letter from the king of Aragon. We never threaten his brothers with actual harm, but even he must understand that I cannot tolerate rebellion. Can we amend relations?


I should display the banner and my crusaders like I did in Barcelona. Can we do the same here as I did in Florance and Barcelona to gain support for the crusade?

1. His feelings of being crushed - Álvaro should be sympathetic but also honest
2. The heir/marriage question - this is urgent and practical
3. The letter from Alfonso V - let me think what that would say
4. Displaying the banner publicly in Seville like Barcelona/Florence

I should have this be a conversation, not a monologue. Let Juan and Álvaro talk back and forth.

Private Council with Álvaro

Royal Chambers, Alcázar of Seville - Late Evening, September 28, 1430

Álvaro dismisses the servants and closes the door. For the first time in months, you're alone with your closest advisor, the man who held your kingdom together during your absence.

He pours two cups of wine and hands you one. His face shows the strain of the past months - new lines around his eyes, grey creeping into his dark hair.

"Your Majesty... Juan..." He uses your name, which he rarely does even in private. "You did everything right. Your speech was perfect. The evidence overwhelming. Any reasonable person would be convinced."

He sits heavily. "But nobles aren't reasonable when they're afraid. And right now, they're terrified."

He drinks. "You feel crushed. I understand. But you need to hear something: you've been gone four months. I've been here, watching this unfold. The Infantes' rebellion failing should have destroyed them. But instead, when you tried to arrest them and they refused, something shifted. Nobles started asking: 'If the King can't arrest rebels, what can he do?'"

He meets your eyes. "That's what we're fighting now. Not their loyalty to the Infantes - their doubt about your power to act."

The Marriage Question

Álvaro's expression shifts to something more calculating, more political. This is his strength.

"An heir. Yes. Immediately. You're eighteen - you should have been married two years ago. Your father's death and the regency chaos delayed it, but we can't wait longer."

He stands, pacing. "Let me think through options..."

"The Aragonese Alliance":
"Alfonso V's wife is your sister María, but they have no children after fifteen years. He might be open to another connection. He has cousins - there's Leonor of Alburquerque, about your age, connected to the royal house. A marriage there would force Alfonso to choose: support his brothers in rebellion, or accept his new brother-in-law the King?"

Álvaro pauses. "But it looks like capitulation. Like you're begging Alfonso for peace by marrying into his family. The Infantes would see it as weakness."

"The Portuguese Option":
"King João I has granddaughters. Portugal is wealthy, stable, focused on African exploration rather than Iberian politics. Clean alliance, no internal complications. Princess Isabel of Portugal is about your age, well-educated, by all accounts intelligent."

"Advantage: neutral. Doesn't strengthen one Castilian faction over another. Doesn't anger Aragon. Brings Portuguese gold and naval expertise."

"Disadvantage: doesn't solve your immediate Infantes problem. Doesn't give you powerful allies within Castile."

"Domestic Marriage":
"Marry within Castile. Strengthen one of the major houses - Mendoza, Enríquez, Guzmán. Instantly win that entire faction's complete loyalty."

His face darkens. "But alienate all the others. If you marry a Mendoza, the Enríquez and Guzmán families feel passed over. Creates as many enemies as allies."

"The French Connection":
"Charles VII has connections. France is finally pushing England back - Joan of Arc changed everything last year. A French princess brings prestige, potential military alliance against Aragon if needed."

"But French at your court? That's... complicated. And France is still recovering from war."

He stops pacing. "Your Majesty, I recommend Portugal. Fast, clean, neutral. We can negotiate it in weeks, marry you within three months. Have a pregnant queen by spring. It doesn't solve everything, but it removes one major concern the nobles raised tonight."

He hesitates. "Though if you want to use marriage as a weapon - to force Alfonso's hand or win a major Castilian faction - Aragon or domestic would achieve that. Different strategies."

"What do you think, Your Majesty? Which path?"

The Letter from Alfonso V

Álvaro retrieves a sealed letter from his desk. "This arrived three weeks ago, shortly after the failed arrest. From Naples."

He breaks the seal and reads:

"To Our Dear Cousin Juan, King of Castile and León,

We write with deep concern regarding recent events in your realm. It has come to Our attention that you have ordered the arrest of Our beloved brothers, the Infantes Juan and Enrique, on charges of rebellion and treason.

We recognize your sovereignty within Castile and do not lightly interfere in your internal affairs. However, Our brothers are princes of the House of Aragon, sons of the late King Fernando I, and blood of Our blood.

We understand there have been disagreements and tensions. Politics often breeds such conflicts. But We strongly urge you to resolve this matter through negotiation and compromise rather than force.

Our brothers have repeatedly expressed willingness to meet with you personally to address your concerns. They seek only fair hearing and proper justice, not persecution by your favorite.

Should any harm come to Our brothers - through arrest, imprisonment, trial, or other means - We would view it as an attack upon Our royal house. We would be compelled to take measures to protect Our family's honor and safety.

We do not make threats lightly, cousin. We seek peace between our kingdoms. But We will not stand idle while Our brothers are hunted like common criminals.

We propose this solution: Call off the arrest orders. Invite Our brothers to the November Royal Council under guarantee of safe conduct. Let them answer charges publicly, before the assembled nobility, where all may witness justice. If they are guilty, let it be proven before witnesses. If they are innocent, let them be vindicated.

We await your response with hope that wisdom will prevail over rashness.

Written in Our city of Naples, this third day of September, in the year of Our Lord 1430,

Alfonso, by the Grace of God King of Aragon, Valencia, Majorca, Sardinia, and Corsica, Count of Barcelona"

Álvaro sets the letter down. "He's offering you an out. Safe conduct to the Royal Council, public hearing, formal trial. It's... actually not unreasonable."

He looks at you carefully. "But notice what he's also doing. He's forcing your hand. If you refuse safe conduct and keep trying to arrest them, you're the unreasonable one. If you grant it, they show up to the Council as free men, not prisoners."

"And that phrase - 'persecution by your favorite.' He means me. Alfonso is playing the old game: blame the low-born advisor, not the king. Give the nobles someone to hate other than you."

"How do you want to respond to Alfonso? And do you want to grant the Infantes safe conduct to the November Council?"

Public Display in Seville

Álvaro's face brightens slightly at this suggestion. "Yes. Absolutely yes. What you did in Florence and Barcelona - we should do that here."

He pulls out parchment, making notes. "The Cathedral of Seville is magnificent - larger than Barcelona's, rival to any in Christendom. We could display the banner and relics there. Multiple days, like Barcelona."

"But we need to think carefully about what worked before and what's different here:"

Advantages in Seville:

This is YOUR city, your power base

Andalusia cares more about Granada than Barcelona does - they live on the frontier

The cathedral clergy are loyal to you

Common people need to see what the nobles just saw

Challenges:

You already spoke to the nobles tonight - impact might be lessened

Granada's ambassadors just left - story will spread that Sultan offered peace and you rejected it
